themes: Exclusion of disabled individuals from cultural life
Need for accessibility beyond physical accommodations
Representation and leadership of disabled artists
Importance of partnerships with disability-led organizations
Call for systemic change in policy and practice
key_phrases: expand its definition of 'serving the public' to explicitly include disabled individuals
access should not be limited to ramps and captions
disabled artists deserve not only to be welcomed, but to be centered
prioritize building long-term, trust-based partnerships with disability-led organizations
ensure that accessibility is baked into the design of any new program or space—not retrofitted afterward
examine the policies and practices across arts venues and institutions in Austin that continue to exclude disabled people
equity in the arts won’t happen through outreach alone—it requires structural change
barriers_identified: Exclusion of disabled individuals with complex support needs
Limited definition of accessibility (focused only on ramps and captions)
Lack of representation and leadership opportunities for disabled artists
Policies and practices that exclude disabled people
solutions_proposed: Expand definition of 'serving the public' to explicitly include disabled individuals
Ensure accessibility extends to programming, leadership, funding, and representation
Center disabled artists as creators, collaborators, and contributors
Build long-term, trust-based partnerships with disability-led organizations and communities
Integrate accessibility into the initial design of programs and spaces
Examine and change exclusionary policies and practices in arts venues and institutions
Pursue structural change rather than relying solely on outreach
